conversationalist: the enthusiastic impression he made on many Americans
attests this quality# Although his main intellectual contacts and sources
of information were among the upper levels of American society, he met
all types—frontier families, etc. (although perhaps not many workers
except among the prisoners with whom he talked). He has a great interest
in all kinds of people. He has an extraordinary memory for them, and for
his conversations with them. He has a great ability to persuade—when
he chooses—as is evidenced by the great number of memoranda he solicits,
and elicits, from Americans who he believes can help to clarify facts or
opinions.
He is primarily an acute observer of his environment and with
equal acuteness he reflects upon his observations: he is a political and
social thinker rather than a practical politician or cur£ leader. He is,
in fact, considered today as a pioneer in modern sociological method, as
is evidenced by the range and scope of his organized analysis of American
prisons and, more broadly, of American political, social, and economic
institutions. He has a deep sense of responsibility to his work (with
regard to prisons for the French government, and on democratic ideas and
institutions for his own project of writing an interpretive work on
Democracy). He is meticulous in note-taking, with a flair for the well-
turned phrase. He is a remorseless questioner. He is capable of being
astounded—does not pretend to cynicism or sophistication.
Despite his physical frailty, he is an early riser, a good
horseman, and teaches his friend Beaumont to swim. Together they tra¬
velled about 7,000 miles by stage, river boat, and horseback—to Quebec
on the northeast. Green Bay on the northwest. New Orleans on the south¬
west, and so to Washington cross-country, landing in New York in May, 1831.
They spent about ten months in their travels and observations. Tocque-
ville is always polite, and genuinely appreciative of the many assistances
given him by his new American friends. He is affable and approachable;
he has a good deal of equanimity, and does not protest over the irritations
of the journey.
Tocqueville*s loyalty to his ideal of mediating between democra¬
tic ideas and institutions and those thinkers still imbued with the con¬
cepts of the Ancien Regime, is matched by his personal loyalties. When
Beaumont is dismissed from his judicial post by the new government of
Louis Philippe, Tocqueville resigns in protest.
Means: (2) Beaumont is to be used as the occasion requires. Es¬
sentially he is like Tocqueville. A difference lies in his artistes abil¬
ity to seize on the uniqueness of the moment. The two are very good and
loyal friends. They agreed to divide the field of American subject matter
between them, with Tocqueville taking all things political, except for the
slavery problem. They traveled everywhere together. Beaumont sketches
the various scenes.
